verses.text: If only you were like my brother, who nursed at my mother’s breast! Then, if I met you outside, I would kiss you, and no one would despise me.
verses.comment: The beloved wishes her lover could be seen as family, so intimacy wouldn't be forbidden. This metaphor stresses longing for unfettered closeness, recalling accepted kinship bonds in ancient contexts. The theme echoes the desire for relational unity, connecting to spiritual union with God as seen in John 17:21.

verses.text: I would lead you and bring you into my mother’s house—she who taught me. I would give you spiced wine to drink, the juice of my pomegranates.
verses.comment: The house imagery represents deep, familial intimacy and hospitality, suggestive of spiritual nourishment and doctrinal instruction. The spiced wine and pomegranates reflect abundance and joy, alluding to sacramental overtones in Christian tradition (Matt. 26:27).

verses.text: Let his left hand be under my head and his right hand embrace me.
verses.comment: This verse repeats the motif of intimate, protective embrace, linking to prior passages and showing the constancy of the lover. Spiritually, it images Christ’s nurturing care for the Church described as His bride, paralleling Ephesians 5:25-32.

verses.text: Daughters of Jerusalem, I charge you: Do not awaken or stir up love until it pleases.
verses.comment: This refrain emphasizes the sacred timing of love, respecting union as divinely ordered. It can be seen as a call to patience and chastity, echoed in the principle of awaiting God’s timing (see Genesis 2:24 for marital union).

verses.text: Who is this coming up from the wilderness, leaning on her beloved? Under the apple tree, I awakened you. There your mother conceived you; there she who bore you gave you birth.
verses.comment: Emergence from the wilderness symbolizes renewal, reminiscent of Israel’s journey or spiritual awakening. The apple tree evokes Edenic imagery (Genesis 3:6), alluding to restored innocence and love, and recalling birth as more than physical—a spiritual rebirth.

verses.text: Set me as a seal upon your heart, as a seal upon your arm, for love is as strong as death, passion as fierce as the grave. Its flames are blazing fire—a very flame of the LORD.
verses.comment: The seal grounds the relationship in permanence and exclusivity. Love’s intensity parallels divine love—a flame from the LORD—underscoring its transcendent, covenantal quality. This evokes God’s unbreakable promises (Romans 8:38-39). The sacramental nature of marital love is signaled by the imagery of a seal, reminiscent of divine marks in salvation history.

verses.text: Many waters cannot quench love, nor can rivers drown it. If someone offered all the wealth of his house for love, it would be utterly despised.
verses.comment: Love’s endurance surpasses all adversity, resisting even overwhelming forces. This relates to Christ’s unfailing love for His followers (John 15:13). Money cannot buy true love or grace, a theme echoed in Acts 8:18-20. The unquenchable nature hints at divine grace in sacramental life.

verses.text: We have a little sister, and she has no breasts. What shall we do for our sister on the day she is spoken for?
verses.comment: This is a protective concern for a young, immature maiden, reflecting communal responsibility to nurture those not yet ready for union. Symbolically, it points toward formation and preparation for spiritual maturity within the faithful.

verses.text: If she is a wall, we will build upon her a silver tower; but if she is a door, we will enclose her with panels of cedar.
verses.comment: The wall and door metaphors refer to purity and openness. Building and enclosing signify guidance and guardianship, much like the role of spiritual overseers in leading the faithful to maturity. The silver and cedar imagery points to preciousness and stability, common in worship settings.

verses.text: I am a wall, and my breasts are like towers. Thus, I have become in his eyes as one who finds peace.
verses.comment: Here, the beloved asserts her maturity and wholeness, bringing peace—the Hebrew ‘shalom’ is not merely absence of conflict but fullness and harmony. This reflects the biblical idea that spiritual growth leads to true peace, prefiguring the peace Christ gives (John 14:27).

verses.text: Solomon had a vineyard at Baal-hamon; he rented the vineyard to keepers. Each was to bring for its fruit a thousand pieces of silver.
verses.comment: Solomon’s vineyard stands for abundance under careful stewardship. Vineyards are metaphors for people in God’s care (Isaiah 5:7). The requirement of fruit links to accountability in spiritual life, reminiscent of John 15:8.

verses.text: My own vineyard belongs to me, the thousand are for you, Solomon, and two hundred for those who tend its fruit.
verses.comment: Contrast is made between the king's and the beloved’s personal possession. This autonomy may symbolize exclusive devotion to her beloved, reminiscent of the Church’s unique relationship to Christ. Fruit is distributed with justice and generosity.

verses.text: You who dwell in the gardens, companions are listening for your voice; let me hear it!
verses.comment: Invitation to hear the beloved’s voice reflects longing for communion, paralleling humanity’s desire to hear God speaking in prayer (Psalm 5:3). Gardens are imagery of paradise and spiritual intimacy (cf. Genesis 2:8; Song 4:12).

verses.text: Hurry, my beloved, and be like a gazelle or a young stag on the mountains of spices.
verses.comment: Final appeal for swift union symbolizes longing for consummation, echoing themes of anticipation found in Revelation 22:20 (‘Come, Lord Jesus’). The ‘mountains of spices’ evoke blissful, sacred meeting places—prefiguring heaven and spiritual fulfillment.
